titlestmt.titleproper: Rockefeller (Nelson A.) Vice Presidential records, Working Papers of the Vice President, Series 18
A Guide to the Nelson A. Rockefeller, Vice Presidential records, Working Papers of the Vice President, Series 18 FA384

did.unittitle: Nelson A. Rockefeller vice presidential records, Working Papers of the Vice President, Series 18

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: United States. Office of the Vice President

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Rockefeller Archive Center has title, copyright, and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them, and has authority to grant permission to cite and publish archival material from the collection.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Over the course of Nelson Rockefeller's tenure as Vice President of the United States, he served on several commissions, including the National Commission on Water Quality. Vice President Rockefeller also served as chair of the Domestic Council. The majority of Rockefeller's actions as Vice President are documented in this series of 63 volumes. They contain schedules, agenda and minutes of meetings, position papers, and memoranda and correspondence generated as part of the Vice President's daily activities.

Volumes 9 through 20 focus on Rockefeller's involvement with President Ford's Domestic Council, while documentation of the Vice President's meeings with President Ford are in Volumes 27 through 31. Volumes 50 through 60 contain press materials issued by the VP's office and transcripts of Rockefeller's speeches, television appearances, press conferences, as well as statements and press releases issued by his office. Of particular note in Volume 32 is documentation of the fiscal crisis that affected New York City and State. The majority of the information was provided by T. Norman Hurd, Special Assistant to Vice President Rockefeller. While Rockefeller was Governor of New York, Hurd served successively as Budget Director, Director of State Operations, and Secretary to the Governor.

scopecontent.p: Information on the disposition of the Vice President's papers at the conclusion of his tenure and plans for relocation to archival locations. Advance Plans. Central Files - Summary (correspondence). Central Files - Notes. Central Files - Name File (sender/addressee). Central Files - Subject File. Howe Files (Classified Files). Wallison, Peter. Water Quality.

Conference (September 29-October 3), Washington, DC. Executive Committee Meeting (November 10, 1975). December 1975: General. Budget Proposal (December 9, 1975). Executive Committee Meeting (December 10, 1975). Report to the President and Congress (December 31, 1975).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Chronological collection of statements, speeches, press releases and press conference transcripts:

NAR Statement at beginning of Senate Confirmation Hearings, September 23, 1974. Speech, Brigham Young University, October 2, 1974. Speech, UPI Editors & Publishers, San Francisco, California, October 2, 1974. Press Advisory, re: More Tax Information, October 8, 1974. Press Questions, on Departure for Warrenton, VA, October 8, 1974. Statement, Laurance S. Rockefeller, October 10, 1974. NAR Interview, October 11, 1974. Telegram to Congressman Edward Mezvinsky, re: Release of Gifts and Loans, October 11, 1974. Letter to Chairman Howard Cannon, re: Gifts to Public Officials and Others, October 11, 1974. Statement, re: Lasky Book and Telegram to Goldberg, October 1974. Statement by Hugh Morrow, re: Delay in Hearings, October 15, 1974. NAR Interview, October 15, 1974. Statement, re: Delay in Hearings, October 15, 1974. Statement, re: Delay in Hearings, October 16, 1974. NAR Interview for German TV, October 16, 1974. Press Conference, October 16, 1974. Press Conference, October 17, 1974. Letter to Chairman Cannon, re: Summary of Taxes, October 18, 1974. NAR Response to Questions: Taxes, October 20, 1974. Letter to Chairman Cannon, re: Summary of Gifts, October 20, 1974. Press Questions to NAR, entering hospital, October 21, 1974. NAR Sidewalk Interview, October 22, 1974. Statement re: Deferring Answering Questions, October 22, 1974. Press Advisory, re: NAR Attendance at White House Dinner for Gen. and Mrs. Haig, Oct. 23, 1974. Press Advisory, re: Mrs. NAR Departure from hospital, October 23, 1974. Letters to Chairman Cannon and [Peter] Rodino, re: Lists of Loans from 1952-1974, Oct. 28, 1974. Statement by Hugh Morrow, re: "New York Post" story, November 1, 1974. Statement to "New York Times," November 8, 1974. Statement before Senate Rules Committee, November 13, 1974. Statement by Laurance S. Rockefeller before Senate Rules Committee, November 14, 1974. Press Questions on arrival at Page National Airport, November 21, 1974. Statement before House Judiciary Committee, November 21, 1974. Press Questions to NAR at hospital upon Mrs. NAR arrival, November 24, 1974. Statement to amplify responses to Questions of Rep. Eilberg, November 30, 1974. Statement by J. Richardson Dilworth before House Judiciary Committee, December 3, 1974. Statement by Laurance S. Rockefeller before House Judiciary Committee, December 14, 1974. Transcript of Phone Call to NAR upon Senate Confirmation, December 10, 1974. Press Conference following Senate Confirmation, December 10, 1974. Press Questions to NAR following Phone Conversation with Rep. McClory, December 12, 1974. Remarks by Foreign Minister Allon, December 12, 1974. Speech, Inauguration Ceremony, December 19, 1974.
